introduction.p: You know that you can make your car move from rest, speed up, slow down and bring to rest, or turn a corner. These are examples of changing velocity, either by changing magnitude or changing itd direction or both. The rate at which velocity, either speed or direction or both, changes is called acceleration.

subsection.title: Average Acceleration
subsection.p:
Suppose we are looking at what happens to velocity during an interval from t_i to t_ f . Let the instantaneous velocity (vector) at t_i be \vec v_i and at t_f be \vec v_f . Then, average acceleration is defined by
\vec a_{\text{av}} = \dfrac{\vec v_f - \vec v_i}{t_f - t_i}.
We often use symbol \Delta \vec v to denote the change in velocity. Here,
\Delta \vec v = \vec v_f - \vec v_i.
Writing the intertval of time as \Delta t, we write the definition of average acceleration more succinctly as
\vec a_{\text{av}} = \dfrac{\Delta \vec v}{\Delta t}.
Since we are dividing a vector \Delta \vec v by a number \Delta t, average acceleration is also a vector. The direction of \vec a_{\text{av}} will be in the direction of change in velocity \Delta \vec v. In particular, the direction of acceleration has nothing to do with direction of velocity at any one instant, but instead with the change in velocity, i.e, how velocity of changing.

shows an object moving in a circle with constant speed of 5\text{ m/s}. In (a), we see that the change in velocity between A and B points of the circle are neither in the direction of \vec v_A nor in the direction of \vec v_B, but its own direction as shown by vector (\vec v_B - \vec v_A). Since the change in velocity is not zero, the object's average acceleration between A and B is not zero. In (b), another construction for change in velocity during B and C is shown. Try to draw for what happens between C and D and betwen D and A.

figure.caption: Changing velocity in a circular motion for an object with constant speed.

subsection.p: Just as with other vector quantities, we can analyze average acceleration in terms of its Cartesian components, a_{av,x} , a_{av,y} , and a_{av,z} . From these components, you can find the magnitude and direction of the acceleration vector.

solution.p: shows vector diagrams of the velocity vectors and the change in velocity for different intervals. The arrow for 10 m/s is taken as the scale for the drawing. statement.p: The velocity of a car changes from (v_x, v_y) = (5, 10) in m/s at time instant t=3.0 sec to (5, -10) in m/s at instant t=8.0 sec.
(a) What are a_x and a_y of the average acceleration vector?
(b) What are the magnitude and direction of the average acceleration vector?

answer.p: (a) (0, -4\text{ m/s}^2) , (b) 4\text{ m/s}^2 , pointed towards the negative y axis.

solution.title: a
solution.p:
Using the definition of the average velocity in components we get a_{av, x} = \dfrac{\Delta v_x}{\Delta t}, and similarly for other components.
\amp a_{av,x} = \dfrac{5-5}{8-3}= 0, \amp a_{av,y} = \dfrac{-10-10}{8-3}= -4\text{ m/s}^2.

solution.title: b
solution.p: From a_x and a_y , it is immediately clear that the acceleration vector has magnitude 4\text{ m/s}^2 and pointed towards negative y axis.

example.title: Acceleration as a Vector on an Incline

statement.p: A car stalls on a slippery road that is sloped at 15^{\circ} . The car then slides down the road with an acceleration of 2.5 \text{ m/s}^2.

sidebyside.p: (a) Suppose, your coordinates system has x axis horizontal and y axis vertically up. What will be x and y components of the acceleration vector \vec a ?
(b) Suppose your x axis is pointed down the road and y axis is vertical to the road. What will be x and y components of the acceleration vector \vec a ?

solution.title: a
solution.p: It is always a good idea to sketch the vector on a coordinate system where the tail of the vector is at the origin. This gives us a good idea of positive and negative values for the components. In (a) below, we will find that both components are negative. If you draw the figure differently, as in (b), you might find the signs to come out differently.

Let a be the magnitude of the acceleration. Using trig in (a), we find a_x = - a \cos\, 15^{\circ}=-2.41\text{ m/s}, and a_x = - a \sin\, 15^{\circ}=-0.65\text{ m/s}. Using Fig. (b), we get the sign of a_x changed to positive now.

This exercise illustrates that, although the physical description of acceleration, namely, 2.5 \text{ m/s}^2 down the slope is unique, the components depend upon how you draw the physical situation and the coordinates. This point is further explored in part (b) of this problem.

solution.title: b
solution.p: The axes are now completely different from the axes in part (a). Now, we do not get any projections on the y axis. Therefore, a_y = 0. From , it is clear that a_x = a = 2.5\text{ m/s}^2.

subsection.title: Instantaneous Acceleration - Formal Definition
subsection.p: Average acceleration defined above does not tell us about moment-by-moment acceleration. For that Isaac Newton, introduced the concept of instantaneous acceleration, or more siply acceleration, based on concepts of limit and infinitesimal intervals, as we have done for instantaneous velocity.

If you find average acceleration using Eq. for different interval values, i.e., different values of \Delta t, you will find that you get different velocities as was illustrated for a circular motion. Newton noticed that, when \Delta t becomes increasingly small, the differences in average acceleration so-obtained become less and less in a well-defined way such that it is possible to define a unique acceleration in the limit \Delta t\rightarrow 0. Denoting the instantaneous acceleration vector by \vec a and instantaneous velocity vector as \vec v we can write the definition of instantaneous velocity formally by
\vec a = \lim_{\Delta t \rightarrow 0} \dfrac{\vec v\left(\text{at } (t+\Delta t)\right) - \vec v\left(\text{at } t\right)}{\Delta t} \equiv \frac{d\vec r}{dt}.
Unlike the magnitude of instantaneous velocity, which is called speed, the magnitude of instantaneous acceleration does not have any special name.

Eq. is an abstract definition, which we can make more accessibale by looking at the components. Denoting \vec v\left(\text{at } (t+\Delta t)\right) - \vec v\left(\text{at } t\right) by \Delta \vec v \equiv (\Delta v_x, \Delta v_y, \Delta v_z).
\amp a_x= \lim_{\Delta t \rightarrow 0}\dfrac{\Delta v_x}{\Delta t} \equiv \frac{dv_x}{dt}, \amp a_y= \lim_{\Delta t \rightarrow 0}\dfrac{\Delta v_y}{\Delta t} \equiv \frac{dv_y}{dt}, \amp a_z= \lim_{\Delta t \rightarrow 0}\dfrac{\Delta v_z}{\Delta t} \equiv \frac{dv_z}{dt}.
These components of acceleration are also called x-, y-, and z-accelerations respectively. In a previous chapter, we have studied one-dimensional motion, where only one of them was non-zero. For general motion, you can expect all of them to be nonzero and you would need to keep track of them all.

subsection.title: Acceleration from Slopes of (v_x,\ v_y,\ v_z) vs t Plots.
subsection.p:
Acceleration at an instant, also called the instantaneous acceleration, is the rate at which velocity is changing with time. In one-dimensional situation, we analyzed by only x component of acceleration for motion along x-axis. Analytically, this was given by the derivative of v_x, the x-component of velocity.
a_x = \dfrac{dv_x}{dt}.
Since derivate of a function also equals slope of a graph of that function, we had used v_x versus t plot to find a_x when using graphical method.
a_x= \text{Slope of tangent to } v_x \text{ versus } t \text{ plot}.

Now, with acceleration possible along arbitrary directions, we can choose to analyze using all three Cartesian directions and calculate derivatives from the slopes of appropriate plots. Thus,
\amp a_x= \text{Slope of tangent to } v_x \text{ versus } t \text{ plot}. \amp a_y= \text{Slope of tangent to } v_y \text{ versus } t \text{ plot}. \amp a_z = \text{Slope of tangent to } v_z \text{ versus } t \text{ plot}.

Once we have obtained (a_x,\ a_y,\ a_z), we can deduce the magnitude and direction of the acceleration vector as usual. For instance, magnitude of acceleration will be
a = \sqrt{a_x^2 + a_y^2 + a_z^2},
and the direction will be given by one angle if the motion is 2-dimensional or by two angles if the motion is 3-dimensional.

subsection.title: (Calculus) Instantaneous Acceleration

example.title: Velocity and Acceleration from Position as Function of Time

statement.p: A car moves on a straight road such that its position from a reference point is given as x(t) = 3 + 5 t + 2 t^2 + 0.4 t^3,\ y=0,\ z=0, where t is in sec and x in meter. (a) Determine the velocity and acceleration at (i) t =0, (ii) t = 0.5\ \textrm{sec} and (iii) t = 1\ \textrm{sec}. (b) Determine the average velocity and average acceleration between t = 0 and t = 1\ \textrm{sec}.

solution.title: a
b
solution.p:
The x-components of average velocity and average acceleration between t=0 and t=1 s are
\amp v_{av,x} = \frac{x(1\ \textrm{s})-x(0)}{1\ \textrm{s}-0} = \frac{10.4\ \textrm{m} - 3\ \textrm{m}}{1\ \textrm{s}} = 7.4\ \textrm{m/s} \amp a_{av,x} = \frac{v_x(1\ \textrm{s})-v_x(0)}{1\ \textrm{s}-0} = \frac{10.2\ \textrm{m/s} - 5\ \textrm{m/s}}{1\ \textrm{s}} = 5.2\ \textrm{m/s}^2
Since the y- and z-components are zero here, the magnitudes of the average velocity and average acceleration are equal to the absolute value of their x-components, and since the x-components are positive, the directions of these physical quantities are towards the positive x-axis.

example.title: (Calculus) Acceleration of an Airplane during a Takeoff

statement.p: The velocity of an airplane during the takeoff is given in the component form with respect to some coordinate system: \vec v = (10\, t, 0, 3\, t^2) in m/s units with t is in seconds. Note the value of t is restricted to the time during the takeoff, which we will take to be 0 \lt t \lt 10 in seconds.
(a) What is the acceleration of the plane at an arbitray instant t in (0, 10) sec interval?
(b) What is the acceleration at t=2 sec?
(c) What are the components of the average acceleration during this time interval? Note this will not be a function of t .

NOTE: Time average of a function between instants t_1 and t_2 is defined by
f_{av} = \dfrac{1}{t_2-t_1}\, \int_{t_1}^{t2}\, f(t) dt.

answer.p: (a) (10,\ 0,\ 6\, t) in units of m/s^2 if t is in sec. (b) (10\text{ m/s}^2,\ 0,\ 12\text{ m/s}^2) , (c) \left(10\text{ m/s}^2,\ 0,\ 30\text{ m/s}^2 \right).

solution.title: a
solution.p:
Taking the derivative of \vec v we get
\vec a = (10, 0, 6\, t)
in units of m/s^2 if t is in seconds.

solution.title: b
solution.p:
Putting t = 2 in the answer in (a) gives us the acceleration at t = 2\text{ sec} .
\vec a = (10, 0, 12).

solution.title: c
solution.p:
For average acceleration, we will average the time-dependent acceleration with respect to time. Time-average of a function f(t) between t=t_1 and t=t_2 is defined by
f_{av} = \dfrac{1}{t_2-t_1}\, \int_{t_1}^{t2}\, f(t) dt.
We need to do this only for the a_z since that is the only part that is time-dependent.
a_{av,z} = \dfrac{1}{10}\,\int_0^{10}\, 6\,t\, dt = 30\text{ m/s}^2.
Therefore,
\vec a_{av} = \left(10\text{ m/s}^2,\ 0,\ 30\text{ m/s}^2 \right).

exercise.title: Velocity and Acceleration of a Projectile from Position as Function of Time

statement.p: The position of a projectile in the air is monitored with respect to a reference point in a Cartesian coordinate system. The x-axis of the Cartesian coordinate system is in the horizontal direction and the y-axis vertically up. The z-coordinate of the projectile does not change with time. The data for the x and y-coordinates are plotted and the following functions fit the x vs t and y vs t curves: x(t) = 40 t and y(t) = 60 t - 5 t^2. (a) Find the instantaneous velocity of the projectile at the following instants: (i) t=0, (ii) t=4\ \textrm{sec}, (iii) t=8\ \textrm{sec}, and (iv) t=10\ sec. (b) Find the instantaneous acceleration of the projectile at the following instants: (i) t=0, (ii) t=4\ \textrm{sec}, (iii) t=8\ \textrm{sec}, and (iv) t=10\ \textrm{sec}.

solution.title: a
solution.p:
Calculating the derivatives we find
\amp v_x = 40;\ v_y = 60 - 10 t;\ v_z = 0\ \ \Longrightarrow \vec v = 40\ \hat u_x + (60 - 10 t)\ \hat u_y\ \ [\textrm{m/s}] \amp a_x = 0;\ a_y = - 10 ;\ v_z = 0\ \ \Longrightarrow \vec a = - 10 \ \hat u_y\ \ [\textrm{m/s}^2]
Plug in the values of t for the components of the instantaneous velocity and acceleration at particular instants. The magnitudes and directions of the velocity and acceleration can be obtained in the usual way.

(i) v_x(0) = 40\ \textrm{m/s}, v_y(0) = 60\ \textrm{m/s},\ v_z(0) = 0,
v(0) = \sqrt{(40\ \textrm{m/s})^2 + (60\ \textrm{m/s})^2} = 72\ \textrm{m/s},
\theta = \tan^{-1}\left(\frac{60\ \textrm{m/s}}{40\ \textrm{m/s}} \right)=56^{\circ}.
(ii) v_x(4) = 40\ \textrm{m/s}, v_y(4) = 20\ \textrm{m/s}, v_z(4) = 0, v(4) = 45\ \textrm{m/s}, \theta = 27^{\circ}.
(iii) v_x(8) = 40\ \textrm{m/s}, v_y(8) = -20\ \textrm{m/s}, v_z(8) = 0, v(8) = 45\ \textrm{m/s}, \theta = 333^{\circ}.
(iv) v_x(10) = 40\ \textrm{m/s}, v_y(10) = -40\ \textrm{m/s}, v_z(10) = 0, v(8) = 72\ \textrm{m/s}, \theta = 315^{\circ}.

solution.title: b
solution.p: The instantaneous accelerations are computed in a similar way as (a).

exercise.title: Velocity and Acceleration of a Car Moving in a Circular Track from Position

statement.p: A car moves on a circular track. A coordinate system is chosen whose origin coincides with the center of the circle and the circle falls in the xy-plane. The position of the car with time varies according to the following functions of time: x(t) = 2 \cos\left(\frac{\pi}{100} t\right), y(t) = 2 \sin\left(\frac{\pi}{100} t\right), z=0. Determine the velocity and acceleration of the car at (i) t =0, (ii) t = 50\ \textrm{sec}, (iii) t = 100\ \textrm{sec}, (iii) t=150\ \textrm{sec}, and (iv) t=200\ \textrm{sec}.

solution.p:
In this solution I will give only the components of the vectors and you can practice in constructing the magnitude and direction. The general formula for the components of the velocity and acceleration obtained by performing the time derivatives are
\amp v_x = -2\frac{\pi}{100}\sin\left(\frac{\pi}{100}\ t \right);\ v_y = 2\frac{\pi}{100}\cos\left(\frac{\pi}{100}\ t \right);\ v_z = 0\ \ \textrm{[Unit: m/s]}; \amp a_x = -2\left(\frac{\pi}{100}\right)^2\cos\left(\frac{\pi}{100}\ t \right) \ \ [\textrm{Unit: m/s}^2] \amp a_y = -2\left(\frac{\pi}{100}\right)^2\sin\left(\frac{\pi}{100}\ t \right) ;\ a_z = 0\ \ [\textrm{Unit: m/s}^2]
The instantaneous values at particular instants are obtained by substituting the value of t. For instance, at t=0, we find that v_x = 0, v_y = 2\pi/100\ \textrm{m/s}, v_z = 0, a_x = -2\left( \pi/100\right)^2 m/s^2, a_y = 0, and a_z = 0.
